article.description:
Carlos Dixon scored 21 points and
Virginia Tech beat (No. 17 ESPN/USA Today, No. 18 AP) Connecticut 95-74 Wednesday night, in the Huskies' first game since coach Jim Calhoun took a leave of absence to have surgery for prostate cancer.

related.description: Connecticut men's basketball coach Jim Calhoun will take three-week leave of absence for prostate cancer surgery.
related.linkText: UConn's Calhoun diagnosed with prostate cancer
related.title: Calhoun to take 3- to 4-week medical leave
related.headline: Calhoun to take 3- to 4-week medical leave

article.headline: Huskies' Okafor held to 12 points in loss
article.linkText: UConn routed by Hokies in first game without Calhoun
article.story: BLACKSBURG, Va. (AP) -- George Blaney shook his head, as if his first game as a head coach in six years reminded him of why he's an assistant. "We were just so bad offensively. I can't explain that,'' Blaney said after (No. 17 ESPN/USA Today, No. 18 AP) Connecticut lost 95-74 to Virginia Tech in its first game since coach Jim Calhoun took a leave to have surgery for prostate cancer. Calhoun told the team about his plans at practice Monday and was at practice Tuesday, but did not make the trip to Blacksburg. He is to have surgery Thursday and expects to miss about three weeks, with Blaney filling in. The Huskies (13-5, 4-3 Big East) shot just 34 percent, had 19 turnovers and were outmuscled by the Hokies, who beat a ranked opponent for the first time since they topped Virginia on Dec. 28, 1995. "We never got it inside. We never got it behind their zone,'' said Blaney, who last was a head coach at Seton Hall in the 1996-97 season. He refused to blame the loss on Calhoun's situation. "I think we were shell-shocked by not being able to pass the ball,'' Blaney said. "I think our attitude was right, but our passing was wrong.'' The victory was key for the Hokies (9-11, 2-5), who are in their third year in the Big East and trying to earn their first trip to the conference tournament, held at Madison Square Garden. To do it, they have to avoid being last in their division. "It's a big win because we know it helps us go to Madison Square Garden,'' Hokies forward Carlos Dixon said after scoring 21 points. "We think about that all the time.'' The Hokies won with a 2-3 zone that shut off the middle to Connecticut's penetration. Coach Ricky Stokes also challenged his team to be more physical and confident, especially in the game's closing minutes. Terry Taylor rose to the challenge. He scored 17 of his 19 points in the second half, grabbed nine rebounds and converted two three-point plays that padded the Hokies lead and energized the crowd. "We got our swagger back,'' Taylor said. "I don't like pitty-pat, not knowing if I can bump somebody. I saw the refs were letting us play and I took advantage in the second half and laid a body on everyone I could.'' The Hokies used a 19-6 run over a six-minute span of the first half to open a 36-21 lead. The lead stayed in double figures the rest of the half, ending on Eric Branham's 3-pointer to give Virginia Tech a 44-28 lead. The Huskies never got closer than 11 again. "They showed a lot of heart. They were ready to play,'' Stokes said of his team, which moved into a tie with Miami for last in the Big East. "It was nice to see them show the fire I know they have within them.'' Connecticut big man Emeka Okafor, normally dominant at both ends, had just 12 points and eight rebounds and wound up the object of derisive cheers from the fans when he had two shots rejected late in the game. Rashad Anderson led the Huskies with a career-high 22 points and Ben Gordon had 13. Gordon was 3-for-11 from the field with six turnovers. The Huskies missed 15 of 19 3-point shots and were just 21-for-61 overall. In the closing minutes, Okafor had his shot blocked for the second time, causing the crowd to launch into a chant of "Over-rated!'' When the game ended, the fans stormed the court.
